records.text:
Explain the difference between supervised and unsupervised learning. Provide one
example of each.

Supervised learning uses labeled data (input-output pairs) to learn a mapping from
inputs to targets, often via classification or regression; unsupervised learning uses unlabeled data
to discover structure (e.g., clustering, dimensionality reduction). Example supervised: spam email
classifier; example unsupervised: k-means clustering on customer segments.

[{"criteria": "Correct definition of supervised learning", "points": 2}, {"criteria": "Correct definition of unsupervised learning", "points": 2}, {"criteria": "One example for supervised and one for unsupervised", "points": 2}, {"criteria": "States key difference (labels vs. no labels)", "points": 2}]

Write a Python program that reads a single integer n from standard input and prints
'prime' if n is prime, otherwise 'composite'. Treat n < 2 as composite.
A program that correctly checks primality and prints exactly 'prime' or 'composite'.

[{"criteria": "Correct primality logic (loops/divisibility checks)", "points": 4}, {"criteria": "Prints exactly 'prime' or 'composite'", "points": 2}, {"criteria": "Handles n < 2 as composite", "points": 2}]

(MCQ) Which sorting algorithm has average-case time complexity O(n log n)?
A) Bubble sort B) Insertion sort C) Merge sort D) Selection sort
[{"criteria": "Selects the correct option (C)", "points": 4}, {"criteria": "Brief justification mentioning divide-and-conquer / merging", "points": 2}]

Interpret the following data table and chart.
Algorithm
Time Complexity
Bubble Sort
O(n^2)
Merge Sort
O(n log n)
Quick Sort
O(n log n)

Students should explain that Bubble Sort is O(n^2), while Merge Sort and Quick Sort
are O(n log n), and discuss why O(n log n) is better for large inputs.

[{"criteria": "Correctly identifies algorithms with O(n log n).", "points": 3}, {"criteria": "Explains significance of O(n log n) vs. O(n^2).", "points": 3}, {"criteria": "References both table and chart in explanation.", "points": 2}]
